skills.name: Identify the net of a prism
Identify the net of a non-prism
Draw the net of a prism

explanations.A: The shape is made up from two faces; a circular base and the cone face which will look like the sector of a circle when unravelled.
explanations.B: I think you recognised this net, but it is the net of a cylinder. What will the sloped cone part of this shape look like when unravelled?
explanations.C: I think you recognised this net, but it is the net of a triangular based pyramid. What shape is the base here?
explanations.D: It is hard to picture this one. Think first about the shape of the base (top) of this cone. Then think about how the cone part would look if it was unravelled.

explanations.A: I think you recognised this net, but it is the net of a triangular prism. What shape are all the faces of our 3D shape?
explanations.B: I think you recognised this net, but it is the net of a square-based pyramid. What shape is the base in this pyramid?
explanations.C: The shape is a triangular-based pyramid or tetrahedron. We can see the base triangle in the middle of the net and then the other 3 triangles would fold upwards to make the sloping faces.
explanations.D: It is hard to picture this one. Think first about the shape of the base of this shape (the darker shaded face). How many other faces are there? Think about how these would look if the shape was opened out.

explanations.A: A cuboid has 6 faces; on this cuboid, 4 are rectangular and 2 are squares. This net has all of those faces.
explanations.B: I think you recognised this net, but it is the net of a triangular prism. What shape are all the faces of our 3D shape?
explanations.C: You are nearly there. This net is made up of squares and would form a cube. How is our 3D shape different?
explanations.D: The net is pictured here. Start by working out the shape of each face. Are any faces triangles? Squares? Rectangles?

explanations.A: I think you recognised this net, but it is the net of a cuboid. What shape are the end faces (the top and the base) of our 3D shape?
explanations.B: I think you recognised this net, but it is the net of a cone. How many faces are there on our 3D shape?
explanations.C: A cylinder has 3 faces; two circles at either end and the middle would unravel to form a rectangle.
explanations.D: This one is tricky to spot. Imagine peeling the wrapper off a tin of baked beans. What shape would the wrapper be if you laid it out flat? What shape would the base and the lid be?

explanations.A: A square-based pyramid has 5 faces; one square base and 4 triangular faces.
explanations.B: This shape does seem to have a square base, but the faces coming off of the square are rectangles. These will not meet at a point to form a pyramid.
explanations.C: I think you recognised this net, but it is the net of a cuboid. It does have a square base, but we need the other faces to come together to make a point. What shape will these faces have to be?
explanations.D: This is a net for a triangular prism. It would have triangles each end, connected by 3 rectangles. For our 3D shape we want a square as the base and then the rest of the faces need to meet together at a point to form a pyramid. What shape will they need to be?

explanations.A: A cone is made up from two faces; a circular base and the cone face which will look like the sector of a circle when unravelled.
explanations.B: I think you recognised this net, but it is the net of a cylinder. What will the sloped cone part of this shape look like when unravelled?
explanations.C: I think you recognised this net, but it is the net of a triangular-based pyramid. What shape is the base of a cone?
explanations.D: It is hard to picture this one. Think first about the shape of the base (top) of a cone. Then think about how the cone part would look if it was unravelled.

explanations.A: A triangular prism must have a triangle at each end and these need to be joined by rectangles. What faces are missing?
explanations.B: A triangular prism has a triangular face at each end (so 2 triangles) and these are connected at each edge by rectangles (we would need 3 rectangles in total). We already have 1 triangle and 1 square. This tells us that our rectangles are actually squares so we need 1 more triangle and 2 more squares.
explanations.C: We do need one more triangle, but how many square faces will there be on our prism? And how many do we already have?
explanations.D: I think you have tried to create a square-based pyramid. We need a triangular prism.

explanations.A: A triangular prism has a triangular face at each end (so 2 triangles) and these are connected at each edge by rectangles (we would need 3 rectangles in total). We already have 1 triangle and 1 rectangle, so we need 1 more triangle and 2 more rectangles
explanations.B: Not quite! We need 3 rectangles in total and we need the face at the other end of the prism. If there is a triangle at one end, what will there be at the other end?
explanations.C: I think you have tried to create a rectangular-based pyramid. We need a triangular prism.
explanations.D: We do need one more triangle, but how many rectangular faces will there be on our prism? And how many do we already have?

explanations.A: This net forms a cuboid, also known as a rectangular prism, as it has a small rectangle at each end, joined by 4 larger rectangles.
explanations.B: A cylinder would have a circular face at each end. What shape is the face at each end of this net?
explanations.C: There are rectangles here, but we would need to also have triangular faces in order for them to meet at a point like a pyramid. Try to imagine folding this shape up to make a box.
explanations.D: Almost. A cube is made from 6 square faces. Do we have squares here?

explanations.A: Not quite. It is made up of triangles and rectangles, but these will not form a pyramid. Think about how the outer rectangles of this shape will fold up to meet each other.
explanations.B: This is a triangular prism, as it has 2 triangular faces at each end, joined by rectangles.
explanations.C: A rectangular prism (cuboid) would have a rectangular face at each end, joined by rectangles. What shape does this net have at each end?
explanations.D: A triangular-based pyramid only has triangular faces. Think about how the outer rectangles of this shape will fold up to meet each other.
